author: kake.com
title: Severe storms and even snow possible on Sunday - KAKE
text:
An area of low pressure sliding out of East Central Colorado and across Northern Kansas will bring significant wind to KAKEland as well as a chance of severe weather and even snowfall Sunday into Monday.
 User: Frank Waugh, CBM KAKE To: link Light and scattered showers are expected on the radar by late in the day Saturday and into early Sunday. the early rounds of rain will be soggy rather than severe. The chances for severe will increase across Western Kansas during the mid afternoon, roughly between US-83 and US-183.
This line of storms will eventually kick east advancing toward Wichita and the I-135 corridor during the evening and overnight hours.
The most likely threat with this line of storms will be large hail stones, possibly topping 1" in diameter (quarter size). High wind gusts will also be possible, and they will increase in likelihood as the storms merge into a line.
While the tornado threat is not zero, it is relatively low. Strong cells that develop early will need to be monitored closely with the threat dropping as the storms merge.
The severe weather threat will fade Sunday night into very early Monday morning. As this powerful area of low pressure, draws in cold air front the north, some snow can't be ruled out. Light accumulation not out of the question, especially across Northwest Kansas.
 Stay tuned for updates and alerts as the system approaches.
We’ll keep you up to date with our Interactive Radar and LIVE weather coverage . Get those features and more on the free First Alert Weather App . With the app you can track storms in your area, stream the latest forecast videos and live severe weather coverage, and set customized alerts to keep you and your family informed and safe.

author: R. D.
title: La Policía Nacional alerta del alza del hurto amoroso y la estafa del falso técnico
text: Secciones Servicios Destacamos R. D. AVILÉS. Viernes, 26 de abril 2024, 02:00 Necesitas ser suscriptor para acceder a esta funcionalidad. Compartir Los hurtos aumentaron un 34% en Avilés el año pasado con respecto al anterior, los robos con violencia un 10%, y los asaltos a domicilios, establecimientos y empresas u otro tipo de instalaciones un 81%. En los últimos meses, además, estamos asistiendo a un goteo continuo de robos o intentos de robo sobre todo en comercios y locales de hostelería, por eso, y aunque las cifras sigan situando a la ciudad como una de las más seguras del país, no es de extrañar que este asunto esté entre las preocupaciones de los avilesinos. La comisaria de la Policía Nacional en Avilés, Inmaculada Leis, mantuvo un encuentro con presidentes y representantes de diversos colectivos vecinales, sociales y empresariales de la ciudad, con el objetivo de conocer de primera mano sus inquietudes y demandas en materia de seguridad, en la que les transmitió la necesidad de que los propios vecinos conozcan las situaciones de riesgo y cómo actuar ante ellas, y estén alerta para evitar así llegar a convertirse en víctimas de los delitos. Entre los más comunes últimamente, y a los que conviene prestar especial atención, el conocido como hurto amoroso, y la estafa del falso técnico. El primero lleva algún tiempo practicándose: el ladrón se acerca a su potencial víctima y, fingiendo conocerla, se acerca y la abraza, aprovechando el gesto para hacerse con joyas, relojes o cualquier otro objeto persona, incluyendo el teléfono o la cartera. El segundo se da en los domicilios, y suelen aprovecharse de personas mayores que viven solas, a las que hacen creer que son técnicos de algún servicio que necesitan hacer una revisión y, mientras uno entretiene a la víctima, el otro aprovecha para colarse en la vivienda y apropiarse de objetos de valor. La comisaria también advirtió sobre la importancia de cerrar la puerta con lleve cuando se sale de casa, para evitar que los ladrones hagan uso de la ‘técnica del resbalón’ para acceder a los domicilios. En el encuentro se trasladaron este y otros consejos preventivos, y para ello, Leis invitó a las asociaciones a planificar reuniones y charlas con la Policía Nacional para recibir consejos preventivos de seguridad. «Tratamos de concienciar de la importancia de que las personas sean copartícipes de su propia seguridad, mejorar su seguridad con un trato personalizado y profesional, en definitiva, a contribuir a su bienestar social», explicó. También recordó la posibilidad de que los ciudadanos descarguen en sus móviles la aplicación Alertcops, a través de la que se puede enviar de manera inmediata una alerta de delito o una situación de riesgo de la que se sea víctima o testigo. Publicidad Publicidad Te puede interesar La señal que te lleva a la 'catredral' de Valladolid El Norte de Castilla Publicidad Publicidad Comentar es una ventaja exclusiva para suscriptores ¿Ya eres suscriptor? Necesitas ser suscriptor para poder votar. Reporta un error en esta noticia

author: Società Editrice Athesis S.p.A.
title: Brescia, in un anno sale sensibilmente il costo della vita: 423 euro in più per famiglia | Bresciaoggi
text:
Era 62esima, adesso è 33esima. Vuol dire che il costo della vita a Brescia in un anno è cresciuto sensibilmente. Più che nei 12 mesi precedenti. Portando la Leonessa a guadagnare 29 posizioni: non una bella notizia per il consumatore.
L’aumento delle spese per le famiglia bresciane emerge dall’indagine dell’Unione nazionale consumatori che monitora costantemente gli indicatori del caro-vita nel nostro Paese, focalizzandosi sui capoluoghi di provincia e i Comuni con più di 150mila abitanti. I dati dell’incremento del costo della vita sono in relazione con il calcolo Istat dell’inflazione a giugno di quest’anno. Secondo Unc una famiglia bresciana spenderà quest’anno 423 euro di più dell’anno precedente, con l’inflazione all’1,4%. Anche nel 2024 il portafogli dei bresciani era stato alleggerito, ma meno: avevano speso 140 euro in più.
In Italia
I rincari maggiori si registrano a Bolzano dove l'inflazione tendenziale pari a +2,3%, pur essendo «solo» la terza maggiore d'Italia ex aequo con Belluno e Napoli, si traduce nella spesa aggiuntiva annua di 763 euro per una famiglia media. "Medaglia" d'argento per Rimini che, con +2,7%, l'inflazione più alta d'Italia, ha un incremento di spesa di 743 euro a famiglia. Terza Venezia, che con +2,2%, la quarta inflazione del Paese, ha avuto una spesa supplementare di 617 euro annui. Al quarto posto Bergamo che, con un'inflazione del 2%, registra una stangata pari a 604 euro. Seguono Belluno (+2,3%, +599 euro), Arezzo (+2,2% e +595 euro), Udine (+2,1%, +590 euro), Bologna (+2,1%, +588 euro). Chiudono la top ten, con 579 euro, Padova (+2,1%) e Siracusa, che, ex aequo con Cosenza, ha la seconda inflazione più alta d'Italia, +2,5%.
Sull'altro fronte della classifica, la città più virtuosa d'Italia è Pisa, dove con +0,6%, l'inflazione più bassa d'Italia, si ha un aumento annuo di 162 euro. Al secondo posto Olbia - Tempio, +0,9% e un maggior costo della vita di 179 euro. Medaglia di bronzo per Vercelli (+0,8% e +189 euro). Seguono, nella classifica delle città risparmiose, Benevento (+0,9%, + 199 euro), Massa Carrara (+0,8%, +216 euro), Sassari (+1,1%, +219 euro), al settimo posto Caserta (1%, +221 euro), poi Lodi (+0,8%, +230 euro) e Trapani (+1%, +232 euro). Chiude la top ten delle migliori, con 236 euro, Campobasso (+1%).
In testa alla classifica delle regioni, con un'inflazione annua a +1,8%, il Trentino che registra a famiglia un aggravio medio pari a 556 euro su base annua. Segue il Friuli Venezia Giulia (+1,9%, +520 euro) e al terzo posto il Lazio con +510 euro e un'inflazione dell'1,9%. La Lombardia è settima con 413 euro in più spesi. La regione più risparmiosa è il Molise: +1% e +236 euro.

author: Sean Devlin
title: Boeing workers strike, PwC to lay off nearly 1,800 employees
text:
Plus, Southwest Airlines announces board changes.
Greetings, comms pros! Let’s take a look at a few news stories from the past week and see what we can learn from them.
1 . Boeing workers strike
Boeing workers went on strike today, rejecting a contract offer from the company that took away annual bonuses and walking off the job for the first trike in 16 years. This promises to halt production at Boeing’s Seattle manufacturing headquarters, compromising the embattled company’s supply chain a time when Boeing’s production process falls under heavy scrutiny.
According to The New York Times
Kelly Ortberg , the company’s new chief executive, had urged employees to approve the deal. “A strike would put our shared recovery in jeopardy, further eroding trust with our customers,” he said in a video statement on Wednesday.
The contract had been agreed upon by union leaders and company management on Sunday after months of talks. It included many gains for workers, but fell short of what the union initially sought. Union leaders had hoped to get bigger raises and other concessions from the company, but said it was still “the best contract we’ve negotiated in our history.”
In a statement on Friday after the vote, Boeing said it was “committed to resetting our relationship with our employees and the union.” The company said it was “ready” to continue negotiations on a new labor contract.
With union numbers on the rise , this incident echoes the Stellantis strike last fall, this incident as the latest high-profile reminder that there’s a right and a wrong way to communicate about labor issues.
Note the distinction in focus between new CEO Ortberg’s message to employees earlier in the week and Boeing’s newest statement: The first warns employees that customer trust will hurt the business, while the latter centers the focus around repairing trust with employees first. Labor negotiations are a prime instance for corporate communications to demonstrate that the “start from within” philosophy is more than a wellness mantra.
When Boeing’s former CEO Dave Calhoun testified before Congress this past June , he apologized for whistleblower retaliation and teased changes to its internal practices but fell short of codifying them into concrete actions.
This is now Ortberg’s charge. He faces the challenge of learning from Calhoun’s past mistakes, i ncluding positioning the findings of an FAA audit about Boeing’s dubious manufacturing processes as a function of employees not understanding work instructions and procedures. Kelly has an opportunity to help Boeing demonstrate an understanding that the implementation and enforcement of new procedures must be overseen, enacted and reviewed by senior leaders.
There are many practical ways for Ortberg to center the narrative around transparency and accountability: It starts with streamlining manufacturing comms that are grounded in consistent reporting procedures, and it ends with an employer brand that Boeing can be proud of. Since Boeing acquired Spirit AeroSystems in July, it now has a tangible opportunity to drive this consistency and knowledge-sharing across its business.
Accountability disappears when leaders don’t codify proper business practices and cascade them consistently down the hierarchy. Enacting positive behavioral change starts with leaders who own and model it.
Trust is the deeper, qualitative outcome of this behavioral modeling. While meeting the demands of negotiations is important, communicators who step up as reputational guardians should feel comfortable conveying that taking perks away at a time when employees are looking for the company to make strategic investments in them sends a signal that the trust doesn’t flow both ways.
[RELATED: Join us at the Internal Communications Conference in Seattle on October 16-18 ] 2. PwC announces job cuts for around 1,800 employees
Professional services firm PwC announced plans to cut 1,800 jobs, marking the organization’s first major layoffs since 2009. The cuts will impact the company’s American staff and amount to about 2.5% of the total workforce. Impacted staff will be notified in October.
According to The Wall Street Journal :
 “There will be an element of resource action that will impact a relatively small proportion of our people, something that is never easy,” Paul Griggs, PwC’s U.S. leader, said in the memo.
“Ultimately, we are positioning our firm for the future, creating capacity to invest, and anticipating and reacting to the market opportunities of today and tomorrow,” Griggs added. The executive said he would be remiss if he didn’t acknowledge the announcement was being made on Sept. 11, a day on which the firm lost five colleagues.
“To remain competitive and position our business for the future, we are continuing to transform areas of our firm and are aligning our workforce to better support our strategy, including attracting and moving the right talent and skill sets to the areas where we need them most,” Tim Grady, PwC’s U.S. chief operating officer, said in a statement to The Wall Street Journal.
Any layoff is unfortunate, and these statements from PwC brass aren’t anything novel or earth-shattering. But they do touch on having an eye toward the future and the health of the business.
While there’s no clearly defined path that PwC shared for how it’ll roll the layoffs out, comms pros can look to the recent example of REI’s step-by-step process that shared the news and impacts of layoffs, and most importantly, gave people the chance to breathe after the fact. In PwC’s case, following a compassionate timeline would have included not announcing on 9/11.
Layoffs aren’t easy for anyone, especially those that are impacted. Developing your layoff comms with an eye toward empathy will go a long way toward making them effective.
3. Southwest Airlines makes big changes to its board in response to activist investors
 Facing an activist investor takeover Southwest Airlines announced the imminent resignation of chairman Gary Kelly in Spring 2025. This is a conciliatory move toward activist investor Paul Singer of Elliott Investment Management, who demanded the resignation of both Kelly, and CEO Bob Jordan while urging Southwest’s board to take a closer look at its business.
According to Forbes :
“It’s time to shake things up, not just stir them a bit,” Kelly told shareholders Tuesday in a letter . “The wisdom comes in knowing what to change and what not to change.”
Six of Southwest’s board members will retire in November, Kelly said, making room for four new independent directors “in the near future, including due consideration of up to three of Elliott’s candidates.”
Elliott said Tuesday that it was “pleased” by the overture. “We learned yesterday, which was made public today, that nearly half of Southwest’s board of directors had decided to resign based on shareholder feedback,” the investor group said in a statement. “In our experience, this is unprecedented.”
Earlier this year, we had a prime example of an activist investor’s attempted takeover of a company board take shape through the battle between Nelson Peltz and Disney . Integration with other marketing and other business functions is key to keeping stakeholder interests aligned in these high-stress times, and the proper response mechanics to properly react to the moves activist investors make. Kelly’s note, while long and burying details around his exit date and the tangible decisions, still comes as open and authentic. Candor in communication, and messages straight from your leaders’ mouths, will always lend your organization credibility when it makes moves in response to critics and help it move forward.
4. How about some good news?
Rumors are swirling about a painting found in a Maine attic being a lost Rembrandt . A Belgian artist is transforming tennis balls into furniture . A Sumatran tiger cub was born at the San Diego Zoo . Ragan Training is great for communications pros to find inspiration and resources. You should be rewarded for your work. Find out how to earn an award here ! Have a great weekend comms all-stars!
Sean Devlin is an editor at Ragan Communications. In his spare time he enjoys Philly sports, a good pint and ’90s trivia night.

author: Mike Bunge
title: Albert Lea Holiday Bazaar making changes due to extreme cold | Freeborn/Mower counties | kimt.com
text:
ALBERT LEA, Minn. – Thursday’s bitter cold is forcing a series of changes for the Holiday Bazaar in Albert Lea.
Several activities have been moved indoors or adjusted and two have been canceled.
"We’re prioritizing safety while still ensuring the community can enjoy this festive evening," says Holly Babcock, Director of the Albert Lea CVB. "We encourage everyone to dress warmly, share the updates with friends and family, and join us both downtown and at the Skyline Plaza for a night of holiday cheer."
Organizers say the updated schedule in downtown Albert Lea is as follows:
Live Reindeer Visit | 4:00–6:00 PM
New Location: Skyline Plaza, entrance west of Moose Lodge
Photos with Santa | 4:00–6:00 PM
New Location: Ignite Nutrition (132 South Broadway)
Hot Chocolate Stand | 4:00–6:00 PM
New Location: Inside the CVB Office (132 North Broadway)
Grinch Visit | 4:00–6:00 PM
New Location: Inside the CVB Office
Kids Makers Market | 4:00–7:00 PM
Locations: All the Things - Studio & Boutique and The Outlet
Holiday Market | 4:00–8:00 PM
Location: Events at The Broadway
Hat & Glove Handout + Hot Cocoa & Bracelets | 4:00–6:00 PM
Location: Hope Church
Santa Cruise | 6:00 PM
Route: Along Broadway Avenue
Tree Lighting Ceremony | Approximately 6:30 PM
Location: Central Park
Cancellations:
Horse-Drawn Trolley Rides
Albert Lea High School and United Preschool Carolers
